1. Let the collection of nonlogical axioms be, (and suppose we don't have any logical axioms)
<math display="block>\Sigma=\{(A(x) \wedge A(x)) \rightarrow B(x, y), A(x), B(x, y) \rightarrow A(x)\}</math>
and let the rule of inference be [[Rule of Inference (Modus Ponens)|modus ponens]] 

For each of the following, decide if it is a deduction. If it is not a deduction, explain how you know that it is not a deduction.

# <math display="block">\begin{array}{l}
A(x) \\
A(x) \wedge A(x) \\
(A(x) \wedge A(x)) \rightarrow B(x, y) \\
B(x, y)
\end{array}</math>
# <math display="block">\begin{array}{l}
B(x, y) \rightarrow A(x)\\
A(x)\\
B(x,y)
\end{array}</math>
# <math display="block">\begin{array}{c}
(A(x) \wedge A(x)) \rightarrow B(x, y) \\
B(x, y) \rightarrow A(x) \\
(A(x) \wedge A(x)) \rightarrow A(x)
\end{array}</math>

== Solution ==

# No: line 2 is not a non-logical axiom or part of the rules of inference
# No: line 3 is not part of the nonlogical axioms, so it must be the result of a rule of inference, but we do not know that <math>A(x) \land A(x)</math> holds.
#
